Did the Fisheries Development Conference at Canberra in February 1967 express the view that a development plan for northern fisheries, especially prawn resources, should make full use of facilities at local ports, especially of those established to facilitate the exploitation of mineral resources? 2. What facilities for the prawn industry existed at that time at Weipa, and what facilities have subsequently been developed there? 3. The report of the Fisheries Development Conference which was held in Canberra in February 1967 considered that the development plan for northern fisheries should 'make full use of facilities at local ports, especially of those established to facilitate the exploitation of mineral resources since, in general, these are located in the remote areas in which fishery prospects are important'. In another section of this report devoted to the prawn fishery, Conference drew attention to problems arising from the inadequacy of port facilities and navigational aids. The Conference considered governments should take steps to ensure the adequacy of these services to meet the needs of the fishing fleet for each fishery. 2. No facilities for the prawn industry existed at Weipa at the time of the Conference. The Queensland Government is taking steps to provide waterfront land on which prawn processing and wharf facilities can be erected. 3. Yes. 4. It is incorrect to deduce that I or my predecessor 'reduced' the total expenditure from the Fisheries Development Trust Account in 1966-67 to the figure shown in the annual report for 1967-68 under the Fishing Industry Act 1956. Expenditure must be compared over a longer period than 2 years, since there have been several instances where expenditure was approved but not incurred until the following year or even later. The reasons for the delays range from difficulty in recruiting suitable staff to carry out projects to nonavailability of equipment, etc. So far as the apparent reduction in expenditure on the Gulf of Carpentaria prawn survey is concerned, the project as approved was completed in 1966. 5. The recommendations of the 1967 Fisheries Development Conference on the matters listed by the honourable member are under constant review by the Commonwealth and State governments and by the Australian Fishing Industry Council. (a) Reports by CSIRO officers engaged on the survey are now being printed. (b) A fisheries education adviser has been appointed to my Department and he is at present studying the education needs of the industry and how existing education facilities may be adapted to meet those needs. (c) No action has been taken on shipbuilding subsidies since there appears to be no shortage of vessels to enter the northern prawn fishery. (d) There are apparently no problems being experienced in obtaining the necessary equipment for northern fisheries. (e) The question of taxation concessions for the the fishing industry is under constant review. (f) Proposals for the establishment of funds for research, education, extension and development are being developed and most States have established their funds. As soon as the total amount of the combined State funds is known an approach will be made to the Commonwealth Government for matching funds. (g) When this Commonwealth fund has been established an appropriate committee will be established to advise me on the expenditure from the fund.
